questions.question: What is the half-wave voltage in a Kerr cell?

answers.a: The voltage required to turn linearly polarized light into circularly polarized light.
answers.b: The voltage required to turn circularly polarized light by 90 degrees.
answers.c: The voltage required to turn elliptically polarized light into linearly polarized light.
answers.d: The voltage required to turn linearly polarized light by 90 degrees.

questions.question: In the Kerr effect, what is the cross condition?

answers.a: The condition when the analyzer is set perpendicular to the polarizer and no light passes through.
answers.b: The condition when the light is completely absorbed by the Kerr cell.
answers.c: The condition when the voltage applied to the Kerr cell is maximum.
answers.d: The condition when the electric field vector of the light is perpendicular to the direction of propagation.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about the ordinary and extraordinary rays in the Kerr effect?

answers.a: Both ordinary and extraordinary rays are polarized in the same plane.
answers.b: The ordinary ray is polarized perpendicular to the plane of incidence, while the extraordinary ray is polarized parallel to it.
answers.c: The extraordinary ray experiences a greater phase shift than the ordinary ray in a Kerr cell.
answers.d: The ordinary ray is always stronger than the extraordinary ray
